Polita is 34 years old and a single mother of 2 children in primary school who she loves very much. They live with her mother who took them into her house and they form a nice and united family. Polita is a hard working and proactive woman who works selling chicken meat in a market stall. She has been doing this activity for the past 4 years because due to her separation she had to get ahead with her children alone. She sells from 6 a.m. to 6 p.m. What she likes about her work is that it keeps her active the entire day, but she regrets not being able to spend much time with her children. But all of this effort is so that her children have what is necessary for their studies. She is requesting this loan to expand and operate her business and she later wants to build a coop to raise her own chickens which will allow her to save the money she uses to buy them.

Translated from Spanish by Aimee Sostowski, Kiva volunteer.

Polita tiene 34 años, es madre soltera y tiene 2 hijos que la quieren mucho, ellos están cursando estudios primarios, vive junto a su madre quien le acogió en su casa, y formar un bonita y unida familia. Polita es una mujer decidida y pro activa, se dedica a la venta de carne de pollo en un puesto del mercado, lleva esta actividad desde hace 4 años, a causa de su separación, para sola, salir adelante con sus hijos. Vende desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 6 de la tarde. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es que se mantiene activa todo el día, lo que le apena es no poder estar mucho tiempo con sus hijos. Pero todo este esfuerzo es para que sus hijos tengan lo necesario para sus estudios. Solicita este préstamo para ampliar e implementar su negocio, posteriormente quiere mandar a construir un galpón para la crianza de sus propios pollos, ahorrando así, el dinero que usa en la compra de los mismos.

loans.use: Expansion of and investment in her chicken selling business.

loans.name: Ninibe

texts.es:
Ninibe is 29 and lives with her husband Nelson, who works as a machine operator in a factory. Together they have 2 wonderful children that are going to school and who are their motivation to get ahead.

She sells groceries and basic need products; she started with this business 2 years ago, it’s open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. Thanks to her good service and management, she has been able to do some renovations in her house.

Ninibe wants to implement and expand her business, in the future she would like to have a minimarket. This is the reason why she asks for a loan, hoping to receive a positive response from you.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

Ninibe tiene 29 años de edad, vive junto a su esposo Nelson, quien trabaja operando las máquinas en una fábrica de su localidad, juntos tienen 2 hijos maravillosos que están estudiando y son sus ganas de salir adelante.

Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y productos de primera necesidad, empezó con este negocio hace 2 años, atiende desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 9 de la noche, gracias a su buen trato y sobre todo administración, ahora está mejorando la infraestructura de su vivienda.

Ninibe quiere implementar y ampliar su negocio, posteriormente quiere llegar a tener su minimarket, motivo por el cual, presenta ante ustedes su solicitud de préstamo. Esperando una respuesta positiva de su parte.

loans.use: Implement and expand grocery store.

loans.name: Juana Azucena

texts.en:
Juana started a business selling shoes in the neighborhood where she lives fifteen years ago. Over time, sales increased and generated good income. Therefore, she decided to start selling used clothing as well. She now has an established shop and wants to stock it more to increase her income. Juana is 44 years old, from Chiquimulilla, Santa Rosa, and has two sons who help her in her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow.

Juana inició un negocio el cual consistía en la venta de zapatos en la colonia donde reside hace quince años. Con el paso del tiempo, fueron creciendo las ventas y le generó buenas ganancias y por consiguiente decidió empezar a vender ropa usada también. Ahora tiene un local establecido y desea surtirlo más para que tenga mejores ingresos. Juana tiene 44 años de edad, originaria de Chiquimulilla, Santa Rosa, y tiene dos hijos los cuales le ayudan ha vender.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for resale

loans.name: Víctor Alfonso

texts.es:
Victor is 23, is single and studying to become an Accounting Technician, he lives alone, in a house that he built on a lot that his mom gave him. He owns a “motocarro” (three wheeled motorized cart) that he drives and manages. For this young and hardworking entrepreneur there are no limits, reason why he keeps going.

The most important thing for him is to finish school, so that he can work on the business full time. He works from 6 a.m. to 4 p.m. and goes to school at night. He likes what he does because he can put in practice what he is learning in school. Sometimes it’s difficult when he has too much to study, homework or presentations and there’s not enough time.

Victor asks for a loan to purchase parts and fix his motocarro to work with no problems, in the future he would like to sell parts and own a carwash.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva volunteer.

Víctor tiene 23 años, es soltero y estudia para ser técnico en Contabilidad, vive solo, en una casa que construyó en un terreno que le facilitó su madre. Es propietario de un motocarro que él mismo maneja y administra. Para este joven emprendedor y trabajador no existe límites, es por eso que sigue adelante.

Lo más importante es terminar sus estudios y así dedicarse a fondo al negocio, trabaja desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 4 de la tarde, ya que por las noches estudia, le encanta su trabajo porque es una manera de poner en práctica los conocimientos que va aprendiendo. A veces le resulta difícil cuando tiene mucho que estudiar o tarea que presentar y el tiempo no le alcanza. Trabaja para solventar los gastos de sus estudios y apoyar en lo posible a su mamá.

Víctor solicita este préstamo para comprar repuestos y mandar a reparar su motocarro, y desde luego seguir trabajando sin perjuicio alguno, posteriormente quiere dedicarse a la venta de repuestos hasta llegar a tener un lubricentro.

loans.use: Purchase parts to repair his mortorcycle.

loans.name: Yessi Pilar

texts.es:
Yessi is 28 years old. She lives with her husband, José and their two children; Sharon, age nine years and Steven, eight. Yessi is dedicated to the business of weaving, specifically putting the final touches on the woven garments before they go on sale. She began doing this work 8 years ago, working in her house from Monday to Saturday all day and resting only on Sundays. What she likes the most about her work is selling. She manages to convince the clientele to buy her pretty garments with great ease and dynamism. The most difficult part of her work is that she is a little short-sighted, meaning that she suffers doing the finishing details on the garments. Her husband, José, and her two children are the driving force in her life for whom she works day by day.

Yessi wants to buy a lot more material for her work. In addition, she wants to enter into the wool buying and selling business, and in time to have her own stand where she can offer her merchandise and also export them.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Yessi tiene 28 años, vive con su esposo José y sus dos hijos, Sharon de nueve años y steven de ocho. Yessi se dedica al negocio de los tejidos, específicamente a ponerles los toques finales para que las prendas tejidas salgan a la venta, viene realizando esta labor desde hace 8 años trabajando en su casa de lunes a sábado todo el día y descansando solo los días domingos.Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es el vender, ella con gran soltura y dinamismo logra convencer a la clientela de comprar sus lindas prendas, lo más difícil de su trabajo es que ella es un poco corta de vista, por lo cual sufre al hacer los acabados de las prendas. Su esposo José y sus dos son el motor de su vida y por los cuales ella trabaja día a día.

Yessi desea comprar mucho más material de trabajo, además desea incursionar en el negocio de compra y venta de lana, y con el tiempo tener su propio stand donde ofrecer su mercadería y también exportarlas.

loans.use: To buy materials for her woven garments and also to enter into the business of buying and selling wool.

loans.name: Aracely Maribel

texts.en:
Aracely works selling mufflers and in sewing. She has worked with FAPE for six loan cycles and has used the credit in both businesses. She began her muffler business in 2002 with the help of her father-in-law and her husband. They were robbed twice in 2007 and were left with very little inventory but they never despaired. With the help of the suppliers, friends, and responsible clients, who had full confidence in them, they were able to restock their shop. Previously their business was small and informal, but now it is a formal and stable business.

Aracely has always liked to sew and has done it since she was 17 years old. She sews blouses in the style of the Quiche region, skirts, pants, uniforms, and all types of things. She has sewing machines which she has bought little by little with the help of her husband. Although they have the two businesses, Aracely wants to use this loan from Kiva to invest in their muffler sales.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow.

Aracely trabaja en la venta de silenciadores y en la costura. Ha trabajado con FAPE por seis ciclos de crédito, y ha usado el crédito en los dos negocios. Araceli inició su negocio de silenciadores en al año 2002 gracias al apoyo de su suegro y empeño de su esposo. Ella y su esposo fueron asaltados dos veces en el 2007 y quedaron con muy poco mercadería pero nunca desmayaron. Con la ayuda de los proveedores en aquel entonces que confiaban plenamente en ellos los ayudaron a capitalizarse otra vez. Amigos también y también por sus clientes muy responsables en mercadería al crédito. En aquel entonces eran un negocio pequeño e informal, pero hoy en día ya registrados y es un negocio formal y estable.

Doña Aracely siempre le gusto la costura, y lo hace desde sus 17 años. Confecciona blusas Quichelenses, confección de faldas, pantalones, uniformes todo tipo de costura. Tiene sus maquinas que logró comprarlas poco a poco con el apoyo de su esposo. Aunque tienen los dos negocios, Aracely quiere usar este préstamo de Kiva para invertir en la venta de silenciadores.

loans.use: To purchase mufflers and other car parts for resale

loans.name: Joaquin

texts.en:
Joaquin is a barber who works in the capital of Guatemala. He began working as a barber three and half years ago. His dream was to have his own business and to be a great businessman. He is single and is a member of a church. He saved money and bought a swivel chair, clippers, a table and three plain chairs. He began with a small shop at his house. After a few months his client base grew so he needed more space and he changed to a bigger shop. He now has a swivel chair, a fixed chair, two pairs of clippers, two mirrors, five normal chairs and one employee that helps him cut hair.

His dream is to have another shop, tools, and another employee to continue expanding his client base and be better off economically. He also dreams of having his own house and a family.

He is requesting this loan to buy tools, such as clippers, two mirrors, five plastic chairs, and an apron. Perhaps in the future he will ask for another loan to buy another swivel chair and more clippers. Joaquin is very happy and excited about this loan and hopes to achieve his dreams.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow.

Joaquin S. es un barbero que trabaja en la capital de Guatemala inicio su trabajo como barbero hace tres años y medio, su sueño era tener su propio negocio y ser un gran empresario el es soltero y es miembro de una iglesia. El ahorro dinero y compro una silla giratoria un cortadora de pelo un mueble y tres sillas normales, el empezó en un local pequeño donde era su hogar y su área de trabajo pasaban los meses y sus clientes aumentaban y necesitaba mas espacio se cambio de local a uno mas grande. Actualmente tiene una silla giratoria, una silla fija, dos cortadoras de pelo, dos espejos cinco sillas normales y un trabajador que le ayuda a cortar pelo.

Su sueño actualmente es tener otro local, herramientas y otro trabajador para seguir aumentando sus clientes y estar mejor económicamente y comprar su propia casa y tener una familia.

Su préstamo lo necesita para comprar herramientas como una cortadora de pelo, dos espejos, cinco sillas de plástico normales y una gabacha y talvez mas adelante necesite otro préstamo para comprar una silla giratoria y otra cortadora de pelo el esta muy contento y emocionado con su préstamo y espera cumplir su sueño.

loans.use: Buy hair clippers, mirrors, chairs, and an apron

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Keo S. R., 35, lives in Sa Ang with her husband, Nghean Chhum, and their three children. She sells coffee and soft drinks out of her home, making US$5 each day. Her husband is a construction foreman while two of their children are employed as a driver and a garment factoR. worker.

Keo S. R. has asked for a loan of US$1200 to purchase a motortaxi for her son. Her son would like to start his own motortaxi service and needs the money to purchase a reliable motorbike. The family sees this as a good investment that will increase their income and allow them to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase a motortaxi

loans.name: Khim

texts.en:
Mr. Khim D., 69, works as a broker, buying cow to breed and reselling them to earn approximately $2.50 each day of profit. His wife and his daughter in law are employed by a garment factory, making about $2.30/day each, while his son is a construction worker.

Mr. Khim D. is asking for a loan to purchase an extra cow for his business. In the future, he hopes to save enough money to open a beauty salon for her daughter in law so that she can use her skills to earn a better profit than working in a factory.

loans.use: To purcahse more cow for his business.

loans.name: Kin

texts.en:
Kin V., 43, grows vegetables and sells them out of her home in Sa Ang. She works together with her husband, Tuy Ky, and they typically make US$3 each day. They are supporting their two children who are students in the local public school system.

Kin V. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more vegetable seeds to expand her crops. She believes that through increasing her yield and expanding her inventory, she can reach more customers and increase her profits. High food and gas prices have led to a difficult economic situation in Cambodia; however, Kin V. is optimistic and looks forward to seeing the results of her investment.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds

loans.name: Phin

texts.en:
Phin T., 45, lives in Phnom Penh with her husband, Suon Soeun, and their two children. She and her husband are rice farmers who work in their rice paddy earning around US$2 each day. Their two daughters are employed in the local garment factory and their salary of US$3 each day is also contributing to help support the family.

Phin T. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase seeds for her field to expand her crop inventory. High inflation has created a lot of difficulties for many Cambodians and the local farmers have not seen the returns on rising food prices. Phin T. believes this investment can truly help her business and can improve her family’s standard of living.

Phin T. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband, Suon Soeun, is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase seeds

loans.name: Sum

texts.en:
Sum T., 39, runs a family business with her husband, Long Seng, where they sell pickled radishes from their home. One of their five children also assists them and they typically make US$3 each day. Pickled radishes are considered a delicious treat, but require a time consuming production process.

Sum T. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more radishes for her business expansion. She believes that by increasing her inventory, she can meet the growing customer demand and increase her family’s income. She looks forward to improving her standard of living with any extra profits that the family can make through this investment.

loans.use: Purchase radishes for business

loans.name: Sim

texts.en:
Sim S., 30, works in the local garment factory, while her husband, Nov Dout, works out of their home as a mechanic. They live in Phnom Penh and support their two children who are in the local school. Working at a garment factory, Sim S. makes US$3 each day, while her husband makes US$3.50 every day in his mechanic shop.

Sim S. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to make two investments. First, she would like to purchase some tools and materials for her husband to start an ice cream business. He already knows how to make ice cream and could earn extra income by selling ice cream after work. With any leftover money, the family would like to repair their home. There are some areas of their home that are in definite need of repair and the family lacks the capital necessary to complete some of these projects.

Sim S. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband, Nov Dout, is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase ice cream-making materials; Repair home

loans.name: Thang

texts.en:
Thang N., 43, raises pigs and ducks in her home, while her husband, Mich Meth, works on the family's farm. They live in Kampong Cham with their child who helps raise the animals. The animal breeding and farming business generate a daily income of US$1 and US$3, respectively. The family believes that they have some good businesses, but lack the capital necessary for further expansion.

Thang N. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more ducks to raise. She hopes to breed the ducks for their eggs and expand her customer base. The family looks forward to seeing the results of these investments and is optimistic about improving their standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase ducks to breed

loans.name: Lois

texts.en:
Mrs. Lois P., 35, sells a range of vegetables to the people in her community. In the early morning she buys vegetables from a broker and she begins reselling them from 7am until 2pm. Her daily income of $1.80 US is barely enough to cover her household’s expenses and her children's education.

To ease the financial constraint in the family, her husband is working as a construction foreman making around $4 each day. One of her children also works in construction, while her other four are students. Watching her husband do laborious construction work from day to day, Mrs. Lois P. would like to purchase more construction tools for him to do his job both faster and easier.

loans.use: To purchase more construction tools for her husband to facilitate his work.

loans.name: Chhem

texts.en:
Chhem E., 46, runs a family business out of her home with her husband, Hau Te, where they sells pickled radishes. They work together with one of their four children and they typically make US$3 each day. Pickled radishes are considered a delicious treat, but it is a time consuming process to make them. Two of their other children work in the local garment factory and earn US$2 each day to help support the family.

Chhem E. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase more radishes for her business. She believes that by increasing her inventory, she can meet the growing customer demand and increase her family’s income. She looks forward to improving her standard of living with any extra profits that the family can make through this investment.

loans.use: Purchase more radishes

loans.name: Sith

texts.en:
Mrs. Sith P., 27, is married with one little child and lives in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. She works in a garment factory as a tailor and typically makes about $2.6 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver transporting passengers to different locations in his town and can make about $4/day of income. The motor-bike service is their main source of income and can save her family a lot of money. Without a motor-bike she will spend a lot of money on a motor-taxi getting to work each day.

Unfortunately, during these past couple months, her husband’s motor-bike has frequently been broken causing her family to lose a lot of income. She and her husband are asking for a loan to replace their old motor-bike. ( Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Sith P. was unavailable)

loans.use: To replace an old motor-bike

loans.name: Ker

texts.en:
Mrs. Ker R., 41, is married and has three children. She has a butchery stand at a busy market selling beef and pork. Each day she makes around $5 of net profit. Her husband is a butcher who buys cow from the breeder and prepares the meat cuts for his wife’s butchery stand as well as other vendors in his town. Each day he also makes around $5 of profit. The family has three children enrolled in school who also assist with their parents' business.

Recently, Mrs. Ker R. and her husband has requested a loan to purchase more cows from the breeder to invest in their business as well as to meet her growing customer demand. ( Her husband is pictured because Mrs. Ker R. is not available).

loans.use: To buy more cows

loans.name: Phok

texts.en:
Phok P., 40, lives in Phnom Penh with her husband and their four children. She and her husband are farmers who work on their vegetable farm earning around US$2 each day. Their daughter is employed at the local garment factory and her salary of US$3 each day, which is also contributing to support the family.

Phok P. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase seeds for her field to expand her crop inventory. High inflation has created a lot of difficulties for many Cambodians and the local farmers have not seen the returns on rising food prices. Phok P. believes this investment can truly help her business and can improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds

loans.name: Khen

texts.en: Mrs. Khen T., 47, is married with seven children and lives in Kampong Chhnang province, Cambodia. She works as a broker buying rice crops from the growers and resells them to different vendors in her town. At the same time, her husband is a construction foreman contributing around $3/day of income. They also have two children employed at a garment factory, while two others are enrolled in school. To meet her growing customer demands, Mrs. Khen T. has requested a loan to purchase more rice crops for reinvestement in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more rice crops to reinvest in her business.

loans.name: Moul

texts.en:
Moul K., 35, raises pigs, while her husband, Yin Young, is a farmer. The family lives in Kampong Cham with their two young children. The animal breeding and farming generate about US$1 and US$3 per day, respectively.

Moul K. has asked for a loan of US$800 to purchase ducks to breed. She is seeking out ways to diversify and increase her family's income and she believes that raising ducks can be a very profitable business. With any extra profits that she is able to make, she would like to continue expanding this new duck business into a long-term investment for her family.

loans.use: Purchase ducks to breed

loans.name: Cham

texts.en: Cham S., 60, is a widow who lives in Phnom Penh with her three children. She is a farmer who works her fields for around $2 each day. Her three daughters are employed in the local garment factory, and their salary of $2 each day is also contributed to help support the family. Cham S. has asked for a loan of $300 to purchase seeds for her field to expand her crop inventory. High inflation has created a lot of difficulties for many Cambodians and the local farmers have not seen the returns on rising food prices. Cham S. believes this investment can truly help her business and can improve her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase more seeds

loans.name: Javed

texts.en:
This is a poor but active man, Javed S.; he is 26 and engaged. There are 11 members in his family, and they have been living in Jalalabad for about 5 years. Javed has five brothers, two sisters and a small nephew. They are living with their parents together in their own house.

After 20 years of living overseas, when Javed's family returned to their homeland, Afghanistan, they found that because of the war, their house was destroyed and they had to rebuild it. So they scrimped and saved and made a new house instead of the one that had been destroyed. They had a little money after rebuilding the house and Javed started a small business, renting a small retail shop. He was able to provide all the necessities for his family and decided to let his father rest at home, because his father was weak and couldn't work.

Javed managed to enroll his brothers in a public school, and he was able to clear 800 Afghanis (about US$ 16) net profit in a day.

A few weeks ago, Javed decided to change his business, so he made a Public Call Office (PCO) and a mobile phone sales and repair shop with his 80,000 Afghanis (about US$ 1600), his own capital. He says that there is a great demand for these things and he will expand his business more if he buys enough mobile phones and equipment. Therefore, he has requested a loan in the amount of 50,000 Afghanis from AFSG, to achieve his goal. Javed dreams that, after repaying the loan, he will save some money for his wedding, and will marry as soon as possible. Finally he thanks honestly the lenders and their sincerity.

loans.use: To buy mobile phones etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Ung

texts.en: Mrs. Ung S., 28, is married and has two children. She works weaving baskets and other items made from bamboo, making about $2/day of net income. Her husband operates a motor-taxi business transporting passengers to different locations and typically earns around $2 to $3 each day. To meet her growing customer demands and expand the quantity of her products, Mrs. Ung S. has requested a loan to purchase more bamboo.( Her mother who lives with her is pictured because Mrs. Ung S. was not available)

loans.use: To purchase more bamboo to produce more baskets

loans.name: But

texts.en:
Mr. But M., 34, is a farmer who lives in Phteah Rung Commune, Pursat Province. He grows rice and earns approximately $1 per day. He lives with mother and is responsible for covering the family’s expenses. He has two oxen to use for his farming business. Now he is facing the difficulty of transporting seedlings of rice and other supporting material. He is asking for a loan of 500,000 KHR ($125) to purchase an ox cart to use for his farming business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL):

HKL is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase an ox cart to use for his farming business

loans.name: Bin

texts.en:
Bin C. N., 40, works in a local garment factory, while her husband, Top Sophal, works as a construction foreman. She and her husband makes $2.50 and $4 each day, respectively. They live in Phnom Penh with their three children and have taken out a loan to start a new business to open up a new stand to sell some goods.

She has asked for a loan of $500 to purchase a stand to begin to sell some beauty products near her home. She sees this diversification of her income as a good investment for her family and looks forward to seeing how it can benefit her family.

loans.use: Purchase a stand to sell beauty products

loans.name: Mercelline

texts.en:
Mercelline is a 38-year-old married mother of four children. She lives with her family in Bware Migori, Kenya. Mercelline is a very hard-working entrepreneur who raises dairy cattle and engages in poultry farming. Her business is able to generate enough milk and eggs to sell in the community. She requires a loan of US $600 to buy dairy and poultry feed.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To buy dairy feed

loans.name: Amin

texts.en:
This 45-year-old married man, Amin U., resides in the Ningarhar province. He is the father of two daughters and three sons. They are students, and they help their parents in their spare time.

Amin and his family have been living in a rental house for about 5 years. He says that it's very difficult to provide the necessities for his family besides 4,000 Afghanis ($80) house rent per month.

Amin U. has a small retail shop near his house. When he opened the shop, he had 40,000 Afghanis ($800) of his own capital. He purchased thread, milk, baskets, cookies, baby clothes, and other goods that are in demand with this money. In the beginning he was able to find many customers just in a few months; he was able to enroll his daughter and a son in a private computer learning course. Their life was going well and they were very happy. But recently Amin U. has been faced with some financial problems, because a few weeks ago, his father died and Amin had to outfit his tomb and shroud. So he lost much of his capital and then his customers went elsewhere.

Now Amin wants to stand on his own feet once again, and he thought deeply to find a better solution for these problems. Finally, one of his relatives advised him to take a loan from AFSG and purchase enough goods for his shop. He accepted this idea and requested a loan in the amount of 50,000 Afghanis. Amin U. wants to purchase sugar, oil, and rice and make some new shelves for his shop with this money. He seems a serious guy and will expand his business soon. Amin dreams of the day when he will find himself a successful businessman, and then he will help poor people, like the lenders who are helping him. He says that he will never forget their boon.

loans.use: To buy sugar, rice, and oil, etc. for his shop

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret is a 48-year-old married entrepreneur and mother of five children. She runs a cereal and grocery business in Migori, Kenya, a venture she initiated in 2001. Despite stiff competition, Margaret has seen her business grow over the years. This can be attributed to hard work, years of experience and her well-established client base. She sells a wide range of cereals including beans, dry maize, rice, millet and sorghum. The profit from the sale of these staple foods helps her pay for her children's school fees and other household expenses, especially during the slow season. She plans to use three quarters of her next loan of US $700 to purchase an extra stock of beans and rice and put the remaining amount into her savings account to use in case of unforeseen circumstances.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand her cereal business

loans.name: Luy

texts.en:
Luy I., age 35, pictured above, is a housewife who stays at home looking after the children and cooking food for her family members. Her husband, Te Peak, age 34, has a business catching fish and selling it to the market to earn an approximate $6 of profit each day.

To catch more fish, Mrs. Luy would like to loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, of $1200, to purchase a wooden boat wI. a motor and more fishing tools for her husband. This will allow him to catch more fish to sell to the market.

loans.use: To purchase a wooden boat with a motor and fishing tools.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 55-year-old widow and mother of five children. She also supports ten orphans in her household. Rose runs a grocery stall which she initiated in 2005 in Bware Migori, Kenya. She specializes in selling food items such as sukuma wiki (kale), onions, and tomatoes. She also sells cereal to enable her to generate more income. Her hard work, perseverance, and good reputation ensures that her business continues to grow despite stiff competition. Rose has applied for a loan of US $500. She plans to use 3/4 of it to purchase additional stock of cereals and vegetables. The remaining amount will be saved in case of unforeseen circumstances.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Eb

texts.en: Eb S., age 20, is a housewife with one child, and she stays at home looking after her child and cooking food for her family members. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning around $5 each day. Mrs. S. would like a loan from Kiva to purchase a trailer for her husband to attach to a motorbike for runnig his business. S.'s husband can speak English, and normally he waits around the hotel to transport foreigners to the temple. Visitors and especially foreigners like to take a motorbike with a trailer called tuk tuk for city tours because it is safe. (Eb S. and her huaband are pictured together behind the trailer they are going to buy.)

loans.use: To purchase a trialer to attach to a motorbike.

loans.name: Nelly

texts.en:
Nelly is a 30-year-old married mother of two young children. She lives in Bware Migori, Kenya. She sells ready-made clothing, a venture she started in 2005. Nelly has received and repaid loans from KMET. Currently, she is requesting a US $600 loan to purchase more stock.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock

loans.name: Lam

texts.en:
Lam S., 56, is a mother of six children and lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. She is a basketmaker, making various kinds of baskets and selling them outdoors. Her husband has been a motor-taxi driver since 2006 and makes $3 each day of profit. Most of the Cambodian people living in Siem Reap operate a souvenir store and some run a motor-taxi business. All of their children are married and only one child still lives at home. 

Mrs. S. would like a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to purchase more bamboo to make more baskets to meet her customers' demands, and the leftover would be used to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. (Mrs. Lam is pictured with her old mother at home.)

loans.use: Purchase more bamboo to make baskets.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is a 49-year-old married mother of 6 children. She lives in Migori, Kenya. She is the proprietor of a small kiosk that she initiated in 2004. She sells various essential fast-moving commodities such as bread, rice, flour, cooking oil, sugar, eggs, milk, salt, soap, etc. She requires US$600 to expand her business.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To expand her business

loans.name: Toeu

texts.en:
Toeu K. S., 32, sells fish in the local food market that her husband, Nuth Iouth, catches each day. They live in Phnom Penh with their two children, one who is still very young and the other who works in a local garment factory. Toeu K. S. typically makes $2 each day, as she also has a sewing business on the side. Her husband makes $5 each day as a fisherman, and the family is also supported by the small income from their daughter in the factory. 

Toeu K. S. has asked for a loan of $400 to purchase a boat for her husband's fishing business. With a new boat, he will be able to increase his catch per day and the family can see their income rise. They are optimistic about this investment and look forward to seeing how this loan can benefit their family.

loans.use: Purchase a boat

loans.name: Nou

texts.en:
Mrs. Nou S., 53, is married with three children who are employed by a garment factory. Her business is cooking porridge and one kind of Khmer food called "Banh Chev," which is fried by using flour, pieces of pork, and bean sprouts. Its fresh yellow-color and good flavor is unique. Besides selling food to the people at the markets, Mrs. Nou S. helps her husband weaving baskets. With her daily business activity, she and her husband can make typically around $4 per day of net income. 

Lately, she and her family have requested a loan of $500 to purchase a motor-bike to use for her business and family's transportation.

loans.use: To buy a motor-bike to use for her business and family's transportation.

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Van K., age 25, is a mother of two children and has worked as a tailor in her village since 2005. On average, she makes around $1.25 of profit each day. Her husband is a construction worker. Normally, he earns about $5 per day. Besides looking after her two children, she still needs to look after her old mother.

Mrs. Van has requested a loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to purchase a plot of land to grow rice. Currently, the rice price in the market is very good, so if her family can produce more output she will soon improve their standard of living. In the future, she wants all her children to take classes in order to get good jobs. Moreover, if she has enough money she will open a grocery store to double the family's income.

loans.use: To purchase farmland to grow rice.

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Prak S., age 48, is a grocery vendor in front of her house, since 2006, and she lives with her husband in Siem Reap province, Cambodia. On average, she makes around $15 in revenue each day. Her husband works making traditional drums to sell to the dealers. He makes $6 per day. This couple has six children, two of whom are students; two others work selling souvenirs in front of the temple; and the other two help their father make drums.

Mrs. S. would like to loan from Kiva via Credit, the local partner, to invest in her family business as following: First, add grocery inventory. Second, purchase more souvenirs for her children to sell, and use the rest to repair her house. In the future, she wants has a bigger store for selling groceries in the village.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and souvenirs for her children to sell, and to repair the house.

loans.name: Sine

texts.en: Mrs. Sine E. lives in Preak Daung Village in Kandal Province, and she is a garment factory worker who makes a small salary to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Song Pol, is a fisherman, but he currently cannot do fishing because his boat is leaking and he does not have enough fishing equipment. Thus, his wife, Mrs. Sine E., decided to ask for a loan to buy a new boat, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy ten-fish-net for her husband's business. Mrs. Sine E. is 36 years old and the mother of two children; the oldest one is a 12-year-old and he is attending school. The youngest is too young to work or study. Her husband is shown on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To buy a new boat and a ten-fish-net for her husband business.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S., 35, sells porridge at the local market each day while her husband, Lim Lim, is a butcher. They live in Sa Ang with their two children who are students in the local public schools. Meas S. typically makes $2.50 each day with her porridge sales, and her husband can generate $5 each day, but they are looking to expand the butcher shop. She has asked for a loan of $600 to purchase more pork for her husband's business. 

The family believes that there is plenty of customer demand, but they lack the capital needed to expand and increase their inventory. With any leftover money or with the extra profits, they would also like to repair their home. With improved living conditions and an expanded business, the family is very optimistic about their investments and look forward to seeing their lives improved. Meas S. was unavailable for a photograph at the time of the interview, so her husband is pictured above.

loans.use: Purchase more pork; Repair home

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita L. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two children in Khogana Dobato. The majority of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. L. has one daughter and one son. Her daughter is studying in grade 4 and her son is in primary school.

Mrs. L.'s husband's name is Lal Bahadur L.. He is a taxi driver and owns his own taxi. He drives his taxi in Kathmandu valley. All the member of her family depend on her husband's income. Now Mrs. Sunita L. is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs 10000.00 to help her husband repair his taxi.

Both Mrs. and Mr. L. want to provide a good education for their children. In Nepal, the cost of education is very high compared to earnings.

loans.use: To repair her husband's taxi

loans.name: Puon

texts.en:
Puon S., 48, is married and lives with three of her children in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. She operates a grocery store out of her house. On average, she makes $5 in profits each day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning around $5 per day as well. All of their children are students.

In Siem Reap, most people work selling souvenirs, running guesthouses or driving a motor-taxi. S. has a few extra rooms that she would like to rent out to support her family and improve their standard of living. She needs a loan to purchase beds, pillows, mattresses, fans and other things to run the service. In the future she would like to be able to expand her grocery business as well.

S. is pictured with her husband in front of their house.

loans.use: To purchase beds, pillows, mattress, and other needs to rent out rooms.

loans.name: Lina

texts.en: Mrs. Lina P. is a villager in Preak Daung Village in Kandal Province. She is employed in a garment factory while her husband, Mr. Sokhuy Doeurn, is a motorbike taxi driver. This couple can generate a small income to support their family. Mr. Sokhuy Doeurn's business now faces a small problem because his motorbike is too old, and he also uses a lot of money on petroleum. Thus, he now wants to exchange the old motorbike, so his wife, Mrs. Lina P., decided to ask for a loan to buy a new one for her husband's business.  Mrs. Lina P. is 27 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending school while the youngest is too young to work or enroll school. Mrs. Lina P. and her husband are shown in the picture.

loans.use: To ask for a loan to buy a new motorbike for her husband business.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita L. (Shakya) opened her gift shop one year ago in the village of Khogana Dobata, intending to raise the living standard of her family. She sells various types of gift and decorative items in her shop. In Nepal the demand for gift items is increasing constantly because Nepal is very rich in its festivals. So to meet the demand of the customers, Mrs. Anita L. is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs 10000.00 to buy various types of gift items for her shop.

Anita L. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her husband's name is Rajesh Shakya. He went to Dubai few months ago for work. Her older son is studying in class 4 and her younger son is just 9 months old.

loans.use: To buy gift items for re-sale

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en: Mrs. Sopheap S. lives in Preak Daung Village in Kandal Province. She is a widow with three children, two of whom are 23 and 19 and are working in a garment factory, while the remaining one is attending school. Mrs. Sopheap S. is a fruit and vegetable seller in the local village. Since her business is going well, she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fruit and vegetables from Phnom Penh, Cambodia City, to resell in the local market. She hopes to increase her income as well as improve her living conditions with this loan.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and vegetables from Phnom Penh, Cambodia City, to resell in the local market.

payments.comment: Mrs. Sopheap Son has fully paid the loan off.

loans.name: Soy

texts.en:
Soy P., 37, lives in Sa Ang, Cambodia, with her husband and their two children. She and her husband, Touch Rim, work together on the family's farm land, growing vegetables to eat and sell in the market. They typically make US $2 each day out in the fields.

Soy P. has asked for a loan of US$300 to purchase more vegetable seeds for their farm. She believes that through increasing her yield, she can also increase her family's income and provide for her future.

loans.use: Purchase vegetable seeds

loans.name: Nita

texts.en:
Mrs. Nita L., 32, lives in Khogana Dobato. Khogana Dobato is located in Lalitpur district. Khogana Dobato is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming.

Mrs. Nita L. has three members including herself in her family. Her husband is Mr. Kamal L., who works in a noodle factory. Her son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs. L. opened her gift shop a year ago to improve the standard of living of her family because only her husband's income is not enough to run her family smoothly. She sells various types of gift items in her shop. Now she is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs 10000.00 to buy different types of gift items for her business.

loans.use: To buy gift items for re-sale

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en:
Thuy B., 19, is married and has worked as a waitress in a hotel since 2003. Each day she can earn $3 in profits. Her husband has a business running a motor-taxi. On average, he makes $5 each day.

Many of the people living in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia work selling souvenirs in front of the temple or running a motor-taxi. Most motor-taxis have a trailer attached, which foreign travelers prefer to simple motorbike taxis.

B. is requesting a loan to purchase a trailor for her husband to attach to his motorbike, allowing him to earn more in the future. B. and her husband are pictured in front of their home.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer to attach to a motorbike taxi.
